title: Analyzing motion on a curved track

content.question: The suggested time for this section is 25 minutes with 5 minutes for uploading your answers. If you find you are in need of symbolic notation that is too difficult to type, you may identify a non-standard symbol and use that throughout your answer. For example, you may identify Q as the symbol you will use instead of the q for angle measurement. A student is analyzing the section of roller coaster track shown above. The track consists of two segments. Between point A and point B, the track resembles the top half of a parabola that opens to the right. The track then smoothly transitions to a half-circle between points B and D, with D as the lowest point on the half-circle. A roller coaster car is released from rest at point A on the track. The car is fitted with two sets of wheels so that the car cannot lose contact with the track. Assume that any effects of friction or air resistance can be ignored.

If you find you are in need of symbolic notation that is too difficult to type, you may identify a non-standard symbol and use that throughout your answer. For example, you may identify Q as the symbol you will use instead of the q for angle measurement. A student is analyzing the section of roller coaster track shown above. The track consists of two segments. Between point A and point B, the track resembles the top half of a parabola that opens to the right. The track then smoothly transitions to a half-circle between points B and D, with D as the lowest point on the half-circle. A roller coaster car is released from rest at point A on the track. The car is fitted with two sets of wheels so that the car cannot lose contact with the track. Assume that any effects of friction or air resistance can be ignored.
(a) State the direction of acceleration at points A and D.
(b) State the forces acting on the roller coaster car at point C and state the direction of each force.

(c) The student determines that the car takes ten seconds to go from rest at point A to point D, that the distance from point A to point B is 100 m, and that the distance from point B to point D is also 100 m. The students also know that the car is located at point A at time \(t\ =0\ \)s, at point B at time \(t\ =\ 5\) s, and point D at time \(t\ =\ 10\)s. The student hasn’t taken AP Physics and doesn’t know how to solve the problem exactly, so instead they suggest that the distance x traveled by the car can be modeled by the function \(x\left(t\right)=6t^2-0.4t^3\), where x is the distance (in meters) the car has traveled past point A, and t is the time (in seconds) since the car was released from point A. In the next questions you’ll be asked to evaluate how well this model matches physics principles. A graph representing the suggested equation x(t) is shown below. A second student agrees that from \(t=0\ s\) to \(t=5\ s\) , the graph could correctly model the motion of the car. Identify at least two features in the graph that are consistent with the behavior that a cart must have it is travels over the track described. Explain how the graph could correctly model the motion of the car during the first 5 seconds.

(d) The second student disagrees with the model for the time from \(t=5\ s\) to \(t=10\ s\) . Identify features in the model (equation and/or graph) that are inconsistent with the behavior that a car would have on this track. Explain how the graph does not correctly model the motion of the car during the second 5 seconds.

(e) Now suppose that the students obtain the correct definition of the function x(t). The students also know that the car is located at point A at time \(t=0\ s\) , at point B at time \(t=5\ s\) , and point D at time \(t=10\ s\). The students also know the mass m of the car. Explain how the students can determine the height difference between point A and point D using the information that the students have.
(f) Explain how the students can determine the force that the track exerts on the car at point D using the information that the students have.
